channel.title: Peter's stats stuff
channel.description: I write about applications of data and analytical techniques like statistical modelling and simulation to real-world situations. I show how to access and use data, and provide examples of analytical products and the code that produced them.

item.title: Truncated Poisson distributions in R and Stan
item.description: Two ways of fitting a model to truncated data.

item.title: Do tweeps with more followers follow tweeps with more followers?
item.description: I investigate a question about the Twitter network, and find that generally (until reaching a level of fame few of us aspire to), having more followers oneself is associated with following people who have less followers, not more.

item.title: Books I liked in 2017
item.description: I outline the stats- and data-related books I most enjoyed reading in 2017.

item.title: Visualising an ethnicity statistical classification
item.description: An interactive network graph is a great way to understand a statistical classification standard.

item.title: Average spend, activities and length of visit in the NZ International Visitor Survey
item.description: Resolving an apparent conundrum where the mean spend and other value variables seems to be higher for nearly everywhere... an adventure in double counting (individuals contributing to multiple groups' averages).

item.title: How to recruit data analysts for the public sector
item.description: Reflections on recruiting data scientists for the public sector, which could maybe be used as practical guidance for someone.

item.title: Some quirks with R and SQL Server
item.description: I note for future use a couple of things to be aware of in using R to schedule the execution of SQL scripts.

item.title: Seasonality of plagues
item.description: Playing around with polishing graphics, including an animation, of the seasonality of plague deaths in medieval Europe, early modern Europe, and nineteenth century India and China.

item.title: New Zealand fatal traffic crashes
item.description: I explore half a million rows of disaggregated crash data for New Zealand, and along the way illustrate geo-spatial projections, maps, forecasting with ensembles of methods, a state space model for change over time, and a generalized linear model for understanding interactions in a three-way cross tab.

item.title: New Zealand 2017 election results
item.description: New Zealand's election results have been released and were within the range of my probabilistic predictions. The pollsters did a good job.
